awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photocatalytic Ketyl and Amino Radicals-Initiated C-C Bond Formation via Semiconductor-Based Photocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of economic and efficient methods to form carbon-carbon bonds is an important role in the chemical industry. Many traditional strategies have been invented based on sophisticated molecules known as catalysts. A common and persisting limitation of known catalysts is that they are expensive, inefficient, and generate unwanted byproducts as waste. Following the principles of green chemistry Dr. Yujie Sun from University of Cincinnati and Dr. Peilin Liao from Purdue University, with funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program, are collaborating to design and develop improved catalysts for these important transformations. Their synergistic experimental and computational project is addressing the fundamental science needed to use light as the energy source to drive carbon-carbon bond forming reactions using photocatalysts. Dr. Sun is developing a new course in Green Chemistry to undergraduates a broad background of sustainability in the context of chemistry. The Sun group is also actively involved in many outreach programs at University of Cincinnati, including UC Community Day Open House, UC-Chem Summer Camp at Cincinnati Museum Center, Science Day at the UC Center for Field Studies for K-12 grade students and the general public. Dr. Liao’s group is involved in outreach programs at Purdue University, such as Purdue NanoDays and the Purdue Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship Program.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Yujie Sun of the University of Cincinnati and Dr. Peilin Liao of Purdue University are developing a novel synthetic approach to C-C coupling reactions on semiconductor-based photocatalysts. Ultrathin semiconductor-based photocatalytic systems, including CdS, ZnIn2S4, and CNx nanosheets, are synthesized, characterized, and systematically investigated for the C-C coupling reactions of carbonyls, alcohols, amines, and imines under visible light irradiation. By modulating the morphology and band structures of targeted semiconductors and matching the redox potentials of organic substrates, ketyl and amino radicals are produced in proximity on the semiconductor surface, which readily couple to accomplish the desired C-C bond formation. It should be emphasized that this strategy utilizes both excited electrons and holes, maximizing the energy efficiency of photocatalysis and circumventing the necessity of sacrificial reagents. Assisted by DFT computations, this project encompasses solid-state synthesis, materials characterization, photolysis investigation, isotope and electronic effects study, and kinetic analysis, starting from model systems for homo-coupling to complex cross-coupling of a broad scope of substrates. Both Dr. Sun and Dr. Liao are actively engaged in STEM outreach programs focused on underrepresented students and the general public, in support of the broader impacts of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
ZnIn2X4 (X = S, Se, Te) compounds have emerged as promising materials for photocatalysis due to their suitable band gaps, chemical and thermal stability, and cost-effectiveness. However, their photocatalytic activity is constrained by the limited range of visible light absorption and the ultrafast recombination of solar-light-induced electron-hole pairs. While prior studies have explored metal doping, metal deposition, and vacancy engineering, a comprehensive understanding of native point defects and their effects on electronic and photocatalytic properties was missing. In this project, we used density functional theory (DFT) to investigate defect energetics in ZnIn2X4 compounds across both bulk and ultrathin phases.

Using both semi-local GGA and hybrid non-local HSE06 functionals, we computed the electronic band gap, band edge positions, optical absorption spectra, and carrier mobilities of defect-free ZnIn2X4. The results showed that despite the lower absorption of ultrathin ZnIn2X4 compounds compared to bulk counterparts, they exhibit sufficient overpotential for oxidation and reduction reactions required for photocatalytic water splitting. Next, we systematically computed the formation energies of all possible vacancies, self-interstitials, and anti-site substitutional defects in each compound, as a function of the Fermi level, chemical potential conditions, and defect charge, leading to the identification of the most stable acceptor- and donor-type defects and their corresponding shallow or deep defect levels. Our results revealed that ZnIn and InZn anti-site substitutions are the most prevalent native defects, pinning the equilibrium Fermi level close to the conduction band edge and thus leading to n-type conductivity. While ZnIn does not introduce deep defect levels, some stable native defects do generate deep levels that could hinder solar absorption efficiency by acting as recombination centers.

The influence of these defects on the photocatalytic performance of ultrathin ZnIn2X4 for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) was further explored using DFT, and the results are presented in Figure 1(a). We found that metal interstitial defects, specifically Zni, significantly enhance HER activity in each compound by lowering reaction overpotentials and stabilizing intermediates on the catalyst surface. We extended this work by performing high-throughput DFT computations to search for single-atom co-catalysts (SACs) in ZnIn2S4 encompassing 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metals as well as lanthanides, considering each element as an extrinsic dopant at substitutional and interstitial sites. For a total of 172 possible SACs, defect formation energy (DFE) was computed as a function of chemical potential, charge, and Fermi level, leading to the identification of low-energy dopants and their corresponding shallow or deep defect levels.

Among the 60 lowest energy shallow SACs, CoIn, Ybi, TcZn, AuS, Lai, Eui, Aui, TaIn, HfIn, ZrIn, and NiZn lead to a lowering of the Gibbs free energy for HER, improving upon previous results from ZnIn2S4 as shown in Figure 1(b). To evaluate the operational stability of SAC-doped ZnIn2S4, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed considering Ybi in ZnIn2S4 as an example. These simulations revealed that SAC-containing ZnIn2S4 retains its structural integrity under room temperature conditions, further underscoring the suitability of the doped system for practical applications. Overall, our systematic investigation offers a detailed understanding of the defect physics and SACs in ZnIn2X4 compounds and provides actionable insights for their experimental design and defect engineering.

Given the success of photocatalytic exploration in Zn-based chalcogenides and driven by curiosity about other related chalcogenides, we launched an investigation of a series of quaternary A2BCX4 and ternary ABX2 chalcogenides, focusing on stability, optoelectronic properties, and defect behavior, via high-throughput DFT computations. These chemical spaces are defined as A = {Na, K, Rb, Cs, Ag, Cu}, B = {Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Zn, Cd}, and C = {Ge, Sn, Zr} for A2BCX4, and A = {Na, K, Rb, Cs, Cu, Ag} and B = {Al, Ga, In} for ABX2, with each compound simulated in the Stannite and Kesterite phases which denote different types of cation ordering. For a total of 540 compounds, we performed geometry optimization to accurately calculate the decomposition energy, defined as the tendency to decompose into competing A-X, B-X, or C-X phases, followed by electronic structure and optical absorption calculations. 354 compounds were found to be stable against decomposition, 114 of these showed photovoltaic-suitable band gaps, and 45 showed spectroscopic limited maximum efficiency (SLME, calculated from the optical absorption spectra) greater than 30%. A glimpse of the complied dataset is shown in Figure 2. Even though defect calculations on 2 selected candidates showed a tendency for potentially harmful defects, this work helped us identify many novel chalcogenide compounds with great promise for photovoltaics and photocatalysis.

 

Publications:

[1] C. Han et al., Advanced Science, 9(3):2103408, 2021.

[2] C. Han et al., Chemistry – a European Journal, 29(33), 2023.

[3] M.H. Rahman et al., Surfaces and Interfaces, 39:102960, 2023.

[4] M.H. Rahman et al., Materials Advances, 5(21):8673–8683, 2024.

[5] M.H. Rahman et al., “High-throughput screening of chalcogenide semiconductors for photovoltaics”, accepted, Computational Materials Science, 2024.
